title: 106_s2517
content: The "School Safety Act of 2000" may be cited as the short title of this Act. Amendments to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act are included in this legislation. The "School Safety Act of 2000" includes amendments to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, allowing school personnel to discipline children with disabilities for weapons, drugs, and teacher assaults in the same manner as children without disabilities. The "School Safety Act of 2000" allows school personnel to discipline students for carrying weapons, using drugs, or assaulting teachers on school premises. The "School Safety Act of 2000" grants school personnel the authority to modify disciplinary actions on a case-by-case basis, allowing children with disabilities to defend unintentional or innocent acts. Expelled or suspended students under this act are not entitled to continued educational services. The "School Safety Act of 2000" allows school personnel to adjust disciplinary actions for children with disabilities. If a child with a disability is expelled or suspended, the local educational agency may choose to continue providing educational services to them. The "School Safety Act of 2000" allows local educational agencies to provide disciplinary actions for children with disabilities without requiring a free appropriate public education. The agency has discretion over the location of services provided. No violation of section 612 or 613 will occur if services are provided in accordance with this subsection. The "School Safety Act of 2000" allows local educational agencies to apply disciplinary procedures for children with disabilities without following the procedural safeguards of the Act. Definitions in this subsection include threats involving weapons and illegal substances. The "School Safety Act of 2000" allows disciplinary actions for children with disabilities, defining terms like weapon, illegal drug, controlled substance, assault, unintentional, and innocent according to State law. Amendments to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act include provisions for changing a disabled child's placement in disciplinary situations, except as outlined in subsection (n). The "School Safety Act of 2000" allows disciplinary actions for children with disabilities, defining terms like weapon, illegal drug, controlled substance, assault, unintentional, and innocent according to State law. Amendments to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act include provisions for changing a disabled child's placement in disciplinary situations, except as outlined in subsection (n). Any interim alternative educational setting for a child placed under disciplinary actions should enable participation in the general curriculum and provide necessary services and modifications to address the behavior. The text addresses the behavior described in paragraphs (1) or (2) to prevent recurrence. Amendments include redefining the term 'substantial evidence' as beyond a preponderance of the evidence. The Gun-Free Schools Act of 1994 is amended to include a special rule related to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The amendments made by sections 2 and 3 do not apply to conduct before the enactment of this Act.
